abstract: The magazine industry is discovering that although Apple may offer new opportunities with its devices, it exacts a heavy toll.
snippet: The magazine industry is discovering that although Apple may offer new opportunities with its devices, it exacts a heavy toll.
lead_paragraph: The frustration that the country’s magazine and newspaper publishers feel toward Apple can sound a lot like a variation on the old relationship gripe, “can’t live with ’em, may get left behind without ’em.”

headline.main: For Magazines, a Bitter Pill in iPad

abstract: Steven P. Jobs, the chief executive of Apple is taking leave a year and a half after a liver transplant. Timothy D. Cook is to oversee day-to-day operations.
snippet: Steven P. Jobs, the chief executive of Apple is taking leave a year and a half after a liver transplant. Timothy D. Cook is to oversee day-to-day operations.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  Steven P. Jobs, the visionary co-founder and chief executive of Apple, is taking a medical leave of absence, a year and a half after his return following a liver transplant. The leave raises questions about both his long-term prognosis and the leadership of the world’s most valuable technology company.

headline.main: Jobs Takes Sick Leave at Apple Again, Stirring Questions

abstract: United States stock futures declined abroad after Apple said that its chief executive was taking a medical leave. Apple shares tumbled 6.2 percent in Germany.
snippet: United States stock futures declined abroad after Apple said that its chief executive was taking a medical leave. Apple shares tumbled 6.2 percent in Germany.
lead_paragraph: The euro fell on Monday, ending a five-day rally against the dollar, and Spanish bonds dropped as the region’s ministers debated a bailout plan. United States stock futures declined abroad after Apple said that its chief executive, Steve Jobs, was taking a medical leave of absence.

headline.main: Euro Slips Against Dollar, and Futures Lose Ground
headline.print_headline: Euro Slips Against Dollar, And Futures Lose Ground

abstract: Apple would have been better served by explicitly naming Tim Cook acting chief executive, leaving Steven P. Jobs as chairman during his medical leave.
snippet: Apple would have been better served by explicitly naming Tim Cook acting chief executive, leaving Steven P. Jobs as chairman during his medical leave.
lead_paragraph: Apple needs to delegate Steve Jobs’s power more formally to someone else. Mr. Jobs, Apple’s chief executive, is handing day-to-day control to the company’s chief operating officer, Tim Cook, because of health issues. Yet he retains his chief executive title. This is the third such move, and this time the handover is indefinite. However painful, a more formal transfer to an acting chief executive would have been better.

headline.main: Apple Needs a Stronger Transfer of Power

byline.original: By Robert Cyran and John Foley
